newsitem.title: POLAND: Poland likely to free petrol prices in Q1 1997.
newsitem.headline: Poland likely to free petrol prices in Q1 1997.

text.p: The Polish government will probably liberalise gasoline prices in February or March next year when world oil prices are likely to start falling, the government spokeswoman said on Monday.
"There are forecasts that world oil prices should start falling some time in February or March. This moment would seem a good one for freeing the prices," Aleksandra Jakubowska told a news briefing.
Early this year, the government said prices of domestically produced gasoline, now controlled by the finance minister, would be freed by the end of 1996.
But faced with mounting world oil prices, it delayed the liberalisation, fearing it would jeopardise its plans to cut inflation to 17 percent this year from 21.6 percent in 1995.

Instead, it last week introduced measures to stabilise the petrol market, including a 400,000-tonne duty-free import quota for diesel fuel, a small rise in official caps for petrol prices and a excise tax cut for imported and domestic diesel.
Poland's refineries cover about 80 percent of the country's petrol consumption. Imported gasoline has no price limit but high excise tax often make purchases abroad unprofitable.
